111894 S2468-8231(21)00511-3 10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111894 Scheme 1 The synthesis processes and chemical structures of the Zn (II) complexes. Scheme 1 Scheme 2 Carbon dioxide coupling with epoxides catalyzed by Zn (II) complexes. Scheme 2 Scheme 3 Chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates catalyzed by oMyPbh-ZnI2 complex. Scheme 3 Fig. 1 Measured and simulated X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of Zn (II) complexes. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Basic structural units of the synthesized Zn (II) complexes. (a) oMyPbh-ZnCl2, (b) oMyPbh-ZnBr2, (c) oMyPbh-ZnI2, (d) pTdPbh-ZnCl2, (e) oTdPbh-ZnBr2. Fig 2 Fig. 3 FT-IR spectrum of Zn (II) complexes. (a) pTdPbh-ZnCl2, (b) oTdPbh-ZnBr2, (c) oMyPbh-ZnCl2, (d) oMyPbh-ZnBr2, (e) oMyPbh-ZnI2. Fig 3 Fig. 4 TGA profiles of Zn (II) complexes. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (I) NH3-TPD and (II) CO2-adsorption profiles of Zn-based samples. (a) pTdPbh-ZnCl2, (b) oTdPbh-ZnBr2, (c) oMyPbh-ZnCl2, (d) oMyPbh-ZnBr2, (e) oMyPbh-ZnI2. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) Effects of reaction temperature, (b) Effects of catalyst amount, (c) Effects of initial pressure, (d) Effects of reaction time. Optimal conditions: ECH 16.66 g, 110 °C, 1.25 wt.% catalyst of ECH, 2.5 MPa, 8 h. Fig 6 Fig. 7 The recyclability of the recovered oMyPbh-ZnI2 complex. Experimental and computational studies of Zn (II) complexes structured with Schiff base ligands as the efficient catalysts for chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates Yuanfeng Wu a b ⁎ Shenbin Shi b Xiaoxiao Su a Zongqi Zhang b Panli Liu b Olayinka ODERINDE b c Guiyun Yi a Guomin Xiao b ⁎ Yulong Zhang a a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo 454003, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University Jiaozuo 454003 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Henan Polytechnic University, Jiaozuo 454003, China b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University Nanjing 211189 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China c Department of Chemical Sciences Faculty of Basic Medical and Applied Sciences, Lead City University, Ibadan, Nigeria Department of Chemical Sciences Faculty of Basic Medical and Applied Sciences Lead City University Ibadan Nigeria cDepartment of Chemical Sciences Faculty of Basic Medical and Applied Sciences, Lead City University, Ibadan, Nigeria ⁎ Corresponding authors. The present work aimed at comparably studying the catalytic performance of Zn (II) complexes applied as the efficient catalysts in accelerating the transformation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized complexes were determined by XRD, NMR, FT-IR, TGA, NH3-TPD, CO2-adsorption. The synthesized samples were found to possess the Lewis acid/basic sites derived from the zinc ions and nitrogen-containing ligands, which can synergistically catalyze the coupling reaction. In addition, the sample containing iodide ion ligands showed the highest catalytic performance compared with other Zn (II) complexes, suggesting that the amount and distribution of the Lewis acid sites were not the primary factors for determining the catalytic activity, and the difference in activity of halogen ion ligands (I−, Br−, Cl−) has a larger influence on the coupling process, which made the CO2 insertion and ring closure of the formed intermediate more easily occur when iodide ion ligands participated. It can be drawn that the catalytic activity of the Zn (II) complexes was simultaneously associated with halide ion ligands and substitution group of the ligand. Moreover, 98.62% conversion of epichlorohydrin (ECH) and 96.97% selectivity to chloropropene carbonate (TOF=56.65 h − 1) was achieved at the optimal operation parameters (110 °C, 2.5 MPa, 8 h, 1.25 wt.% catalyst of ECH). Furthermore, the proposed pathway of CO2 coupling with epoxide was confirmed by DFT calculation, with the result confirming that the process of epoxide ring opening was the key step for the coupling reaction. Graphical abstract Chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates over Zn (II) Schiff base complex Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 Epoxides Cyclic carbonates Zn (II) complexes DFT 1 Introduction The rapid increasing amount of CO2 emissions from fossil fuel combustion has caused a series of negative influence on the climate as well as sustainable development [1, 2]. Hence, finding the transformation routes for CO2 utilization is profound both for academic research and environmental protection. Interestingly, carbon dioxide with excellent physicochemical properties (inexpensiveness, nontoxic, harmlessness, renewability) has been applied as C1 resource to participate in the synthesis of fine chemicals [3-7]. Among the synthesized chemicals, cyclic carbonates derived from CO2 cycloaddition have been found with wide industrial applications [8-12]. For example, the use of the synthesized cyclic carbonates as intermediates for the synthesis of polyester (polycarbonates and polyurethanes), pharmaceutically important compounds have also been performed widely. Besides, the cyclic carbonates can also serve as polar solvents, and electrolytes in lithium secondary batteries. At present, the coupling reactions between CO2 and epoxides have been promoted by various catalysts containing the homogeneous alkali metal halides [13-15], quaternary ammonium or phosponium salts [16, 17], functional polymer [18-20], ionic liquids [21-23], heterogeneous metal oxides [24-26], covalent organic framework materials [27, 28], and metal-organic frameworks [29, 30], of which the separation for reobtaining the homogeneous catalysts was difficult to carried out, while some reaction systems always required harsh conditions. Hence, this has stimulated some researchers in the past years to pursue the studies of finding highly-efficient catalysts for catalytic transformation of carbon dioxide into cyclic carbonates. The metal-based complexes constructed with metal ions and nitrogen-containing ligand can exhibit the dual functions of Lewis acid-basic sites, which have been widely explored for accelerating the catalytic process of CO2 insertion into epoxide [31-35]. For example, bimetallic aluminum-salen complexes together with tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was found with the relatively high catalytic activity for promoting cyclic carbonates synthesis [36, 37]. Besides, carbon dioxide coupling with epoxides can be efficiently enhanced by Al complexes constructed with amine-bridged poly(phenolato) ligands, and when TBAB was employed, 60–97% yield of the cyclic carbonates was obtained [38]. In addition, the catalytic activity for CO2/epoxide copolymerization was remarkably enhanced after the Co ions-containing salen complexes were functionalized by quaternary ammonium salt [39]. Moreover, when M(salphen) complexes (M=Zn, Cu, and Ni) modified by N-methylhomopiperazine were employed, increasing catalytic activity for propylene carbonate synthesis was observed, and the yield was in the order: 92% (Zn) > 68% (Cu) > 27% (Zn) [40]. Furthermore, when bis(phenoxyiminato)Fe(III)‑chloro complexes and cocatalyst (DMAP, Bu4NBr, Bu4PBr) were simultaneously added in the coupling reaction performed at 120 °C for 24 h, the conversion of propylene oxide was respectively observed with 79%(DMAP), 75%(Bu4NBr), and 83%(DMAP) [41]. The reason for all the reported complexes having the ability to promote CO2 cycloaddition was due to the presence of Lewis acid-basic sites within its structure, and the bifunctional species can synergistically catalyze the three steps of CO2 cycloaddition (ring opening of epoxide, CO2 insertion, and ring closure for cyclic carbonate). In this work, five kinds of Zn (II) complexes were synthesized, and applied as the catalysts for promoting CO2 cycloaddition. Some reaction conditions including reaction temperature, initial pressure, reaction time, catalyst amount and recyclability were systemically investigated with epichlorohydrin as the probe, while the coupling scope of epoxide with CO2 was also extensively studied under the optimal conditions. Finally, a proposed reaction pathway was confirmed by DFT calculations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Zn (II) complexes Five kinds of Zn (II) complexes were synthesized reference to previous reports (Scheme 1 ) [42, 43], which was described as follows: Synthesis of oMyPbh-ZnCl2(1). 10 mL ethanol solution including 2-Pyridinecarboxaldehyde (1.2 mmol) was added dropwise into o-Methoxyaniline (1.2 mmol) methanol solution (10 mL). After being stirred for 2 h, 40 mL ethanol solution including ZnCl2 (1.1 mmol) was added into the mixed solution, which brought about the rapid formation of a yellow precipitate. The system was continuously stirred for another 48 h. Subsequently, the newly-formed complex was filtered and washed with ethanol three times (3 × 5 mL), followed by being dried under vacuum. The precipitate was dissolved into 50 mL boiling acetonitrile, and obtained via hot filtration. (Fig.S5 and Fig.S10) 2.2 Catalyst reaction The catalytic performance of the synthesized samples was evaluated via enhancing CO2 coupling with epoxide to form cyclic carbonate (CLC) performed in a stainless autoclave (100 mL), and the control parameters were monitored by the electromagnetic stirrer and thermocouple (>Scheme 2 ). During the catalytic activity test, the epoxide and catalyst were firstly charged into reactor which was sealed, and pressurized with CO2 after the system have been purified thrice. Subsequently, the reaction system was stirred and heated to the setting parameters. After the reaction had continued for 8 h, the reaction system was cooled down to 5 °C in an ice bath. The catalyst-free liquid and recovered solid were thereafter obtained via centrifugation, after which the organic liquid was analyzed by gas chromatography. Reactant conversion and product selectivity were measured reference to Eq. (1) and (2). (When propylene oxide reacted with CO2, the purification process was omitted) (1) Epoxide conversion = amount of epoxid e i n i t i a l − amount of epoxid e r e s i d u a l amount of epoxid e i n i t i a l × 100 % (2) CLCselectivity = amount of CL C f o r m e d amount of CL C f o r m e d + amount of by − products × 100 % 2.3 Characterization and computational details Crystal structure of the synthesized Zn (II) complexes was determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) instrument equipped with Cu Kα radiation, and the data were collected in 2θ range of 5–60° with a scan speed of 10 o/min. The chemical groups of the synthesized Zn (II) complexes were identified by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra performed on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer, and the spectra was recorded in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with KBr as fixative. CO2-adsorption profiles and adsorption capacity of the synthesized samples were measured at room temperature on a Beishide 3H-2000 analyzer after the samples have been outgassed at 120 °C for 12 h. The thermostability of the Zn (II) complexes was determined by Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) conducted on a SDT Q600 thermal analyzer. During the record, the sample was linearly heated from 30 to 600 °C (10 °/min) with the nitrogen as protective gas. CO2/NH3-TPD profiles of the synthesized samples were determined via temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide/ammonia on the TP-5056 equipment. During the test, the sample was firstly heated at 150 °C for 1 h under helium atmosphere. After being cooled down to 30 °C, the sample was then exposed in 30 mL/min NH3/CO2 airflow for 30 min. Thereafter, the system was purged with helium for another 30 min to exclude physical residual gas, and then the sample was heated to 400 °C with a liner rate of 10 °C/min, and the released gas from the sample was recorded via TCD detector. The composition and content of the catalyst-free liquid were detected by GC-6890 instrument equipped with SE-54 capillary column, of which ethylene glycol monobutyl ether was selected as the internal standard. The geometric structure including CO2, ECH, CPC, intermediates and transition states were optimized by G09 packages, of which ECP-based LANL2DZ for Zn atom and 6–311G(d, p) for main-group atoms basis set together with M06 exchange functional were applied for the optimal structure search. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Zn (II) complexes The measured and simulated crystal data of Zn (II) complexes were exhibited in Fig. 1. It was observed that the experimentally-measured patterns were in well consistent with the simulated data, which were also validated by previous reports [42, 43]. As a result, all the studied Zn (II) complexes were successfully prepared. The basic structural units of the Zn (II) complexes were displayed in Fig. 2. For oMyPbh-ZnCl2, oMyPbh-ZnBr2, and oMyPbh-ZnI2 compounds, zinc ion was simultaneously coordinated with two nitrogen atoms, oxygen atom and two halogen atoms, while, zinc ion was linked to two nitrogen atoms and two halogen atoms in pTdPbh-ZnCl2, oTdPbh-ZnBr2, and pNlPbh-ZnBr2. More importantly, zinc ions within the crystal structure have the ability to promote the acid-catalyzed reaction, and nitrogen-containing groups can be provided with Lewis basic sites function. As a result, the synthesized Zn (II) complexes can enhance CO2 insertion into epoxide [44, 45]. FT-IR spectra of the Zn (II) complexes were displayed in Fig. 3. Similar spectra were observed for oMyPbh-ZnCl2, oMyPbh-ZnBr2, and oMyPbh-ZnI2, which was due to the three samples being constructed with the same ligand, additionally, the bands centered at 1255 cm−1 and 1018 cm−1 were related to anti-symmetric stretching vibration and symmetric stretching vibration of C-O-C groups [46, 47]. While the band located at 1024 cm−1 for pTdPbh-ZnCl2 and oTdPbh-ZnBr2 was attributed to the rocking vibration of methyl groups [48, 49]. For all the samples, the band peak at 1590 cm−1 corresponds to the symmetric stretching vibration of C = N groups [42, 43], demonstrated that the characteristic bond of C = N within the ligands were formed during the sample preparation. The thermal behaviors of the synthesized Zn (II) complexes were detected in the range of 30–600 °C, and the weight loss recorded at the heating rate of 10 °C/min in nitrogen flow, with the results being presented in Fig. 4. Interestingly, the as-synthesized four kinds of Zn (II) complexes maintained a constant weight until the temperature was beyond 274 °C, while the decomposition of pTdPbh-ZnCl2 sample occurred at a higher temperature (320 °C), suggesting that all the synthesized samples can withstand a high temperature without structural collapse. Due to absence of carboxylic groups and hydroxyl groups within all the sample, the active sites detected by NH3-TPD corresponded to Lewis instead of Brönsted acid sites. As a result, the desorption area appearing in Fig. 5I was associated with Lewis acid sites, of which the area appearing in the range of 30–200 °C and 200–400 °C were assigned to weak and moderate Lewis acid sites, respectively. Moreover, oMyPbh-ZnCl2 was found with the desorption area peak at 266 °C which was higher than that of oMyPbh-ZnI2 and oMyPbh-ZnBr2, implying that oMyPbh-ZnCl2 has the highest catalytic activity among the same-ligand compounds. Also, the second NH3 desorption peak appeared at 266 °C for oMyPbh-ZnCl2 and 220 °C for oMyPbh-ZnI2, respectively, indicating that the two samples were provided with moderate acid sites. For pTdPbh-ZnCl2 and oTdPbh-ZnBr2, the NH3 desorption peak only appeared in the range of 80–170 °C, suggesting that only the weak Lewis acid sites were formed inside the three samples. Additionally, CO2-TPD profile of oMyPbh-ZnI2 as shown in Fig. 5I(e), was observed without any desorption area below the decomposition temperature (Fig. 4), possibly caused by the strong interaction between CO2 molecule and basic sites, which make CO2 desorption from the active sites difficult. To confirm the existence of Lewis basic sites within the samples, CO2 adsorption was performed with the results being shown in Fig. 5II. Interestingly, Zn (II) complexes observed with various adsorption capacities of CO2, suggesting that Lewis basic sites existed in the synthesized samples. Furthermore, oMyPbh-ZnCl2 was observed with the highest adsorption capacity, and the lowest adsorption capacity was observed over oMyPbh-ZnBr2, implying that halogen ion ligands also have a large effect on the formation of basic sites. According to the characterization results, the synthesized Zn (II) complexes have the ability to enhance transformation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. 3.2 CO2 coupling with ECH and optimized parameters The conversion of ECH and selectivity to CPC was applied as the determining parameters for evaluating the catalytic performance of the Zn (II) complexes, with the catalytic results being listed in Table 1 . Among all the studied samples, oMyPbh-ZnI2 was found to possess the highest catalytic activity. Besides, for the same-ligand samples (oMyPbh-ZnCl2, oMyPbh-ZnBr2, oMyPbh-ZnI2), the catalytic activity was in the order: oMyPbh-ZnI2 (56.11%) > oMyPbh-ZnBr2 (53.45%) > oMyPbh-ZnCl2 (39.65%), while the oMyPbh-ZnCl2 was observed with more Lewis acid sites (Fig. 5I), demonstrated that the amount and distribution of the Lewis acid sites were not the primary factors for determining the catalytic activity, and the difference in activity of halogen ion ligands (I−, Br−, Cl−) can account for the various ECH conversion, of which CO2 insertion and ring closure of the formed intermediate easily occurring when iodide ion ligands participated in the coupling reaction (Fig. 9). Besides, this may be associated with the hydrogen bond interactions for the total Hirsheld surfaces (Fig. S13–14):37.2% (I…H)> 36.0% (Br…H)> 32.6% (Cl…H). Moreover, the multiple hydrogen bonding donor together with protic ammonium bromide has been confirmed with the catalytic performance for CO2 coupling with epoxide [50]. While, the conversion of ECH decrease from 53.41% to 40.57% when oTdPbh-ZnBr2 was replaced by pTdPbh-ZnCl2, indicating that the activity of bromide ion was higher than chloride ion although the larger Steric hindrance would be formed between active sites and reactant when the coupling process was enhanced by oTdPbh-ZnBr2. Besides, higher acidity of Lewis acid sites (Fig. 5I) within solid can also endow oTdPbh-ZnBr2 with higher catalytic activity. Moreover, some complexes structured similar with the all above have been reported with the feature of spontaneously producing dimeric structures both in solid state and in the reaction media, which could improve the catalytic performances during the reaction [51-54]. The catalytic activity of the Zn (II) complexes for CO2 cycloaddition was simultaneously related to halide ion ligands and substitution group of the ligand. As a result, oMyPbh-ZnI2 was selected to optimize the operating parameters. Reaction temperature as one of the important operating parameters is usually optimized to indicate the reactants with high conversion and minima side reaction. As Fig. 6a presented that the conversion of ECH showed a rapid increase from 46.11% (80 °C) to 85.14% (110 °C), and then slightly increased to 90.12% (120 °C), while the CPC selectivity exhibited an obvious decrease with the temperature above 110 °C. The decreasing CPC selectivity was attributed to the dissociation of limited water from catalyst solid: the dissociated water reacted with ECH to form 3‑chloro-1,2-propanediol (Fig. S11). Hence, to obtain a high conversion of ECH with less by-products, 110 °C can be considered as the most suitable reaction temperature for exploring subsequent parameters. The content of oMyPbh-ZnI2 complex within the organic liquid was optimized via detection of ECH conversion and CPC selectivity, with the results being displayed in Fig. 6b. The conversion of ECH showed a continuous uptrend from 56.95% (0.5 wt.% of ECH) to 95.06% (1.5 wt.% of ECH) with the catalyst amount increase, and when the catalyst amount was above 1.25 wt.% of ECH, the conversion of ECH only show a slow rise. Thus, 1.25 wt.% of ECH was regarded as the optimal catalyst concentration for the fixed catalytic system. The amount of CO2 effecting the ECH conversion was studied at the initial pressure range of 2.0 - 3.5 MPa. The conversion of ECH observed in Fig. 6c exhibited an obvious increase, maximizing to 92.62% (2.5 MPa), followed by decrease to 74.16% (3.5 MPa), while the selectivity to ECH only show a slight fluctuation with the pressure rise. The increasing conversion along with pressure change is attributed to the appropriate CO2 concentration which could make as many molecules as possible participate in the coupling reaction [55]. Moreover, excessive pressure can also make the ECH molecules get diluted around the active sites [56, 57], resulting in a decreasing reactant conversion. As a result, charging the reactor with 2.5 MPa of CO2 gas is most suitable for promoting the coupling reaction. The ECH conversion together with CPC selectivity gradually changed with the prolonging of reaction time. Therefore, intermittent detection of the continuously-changing component distribution is necessary to achieve the satisfactory product yield in a short time. The results of component change versus reaction time is displayed in Fig. 6d. The ECH conversion was found with a rapid increase when the reaction time was prolonged from second hour (28.19%) to sixth hour (95.65%), then showed a slow increase to 98.62% (eighth hour). This was thereafter followed by a slight fluctuation with increased timing, which is related to the rapid formation of CPC alongside with ECH conversion [58]. Furthermore, a slight decrease in the CPC selectivity was observed during the coupling reaction, suggesting that only a small quantity of ECH was hydrolyzed into 3‑chloro-1,2-propanediol. Thus, reaction time of 8 h was beneficial for gaining a satisfactory CPC yield. As mentioned earlier, the highest catalytic activity was observed with 98.62% conversion of epichlorohydrin and 96.97% selectivity to chloropropene carbonate (TOF=56.65 h − 1) once the coupling reaction was performed at the optimized conditions. 3.3 Recyclability of the Zn-based complex The recyclability is the important parameter for the evaluation of the Zn-based complex, which is usually reused at the optimal reaction conditions. During the catalytic cycle, most sample was regained via centrifugation, while another part was recovered from organic liquid via water extraction, after which it was further treated via rotary evaporation to remove the water. Subsequently, both parts were simultaneously added into the catalytic system for enhancing CO2 conversion (Fig. 7). When the recovered experiment was performed three times, only a slight decrease in ECH conversion was observed, suggesting that the synthesized Zn (II) complexes was table in catalytic performance during the liquid reaction. However, the conversion of ECH displayed an obvious decrease for the fourth cycle, which may be ascribed to the adsorbed organic component covering the surface of oMyPbh-ZnI2 complex, hence making the reactant contact with the active sites difficultly. Besides, the structure collapse of the recovered sample may be also a reason for this case (Fig. S15). 3.4 CO2 cycloaddition with other epoxides The coupling scope of oMyPbh-ZnI2 being used as the catalyst for enhancing CO2 cycloaddition was investigated with ECH, styrene oxide (SO), propylene oxide (PO), allyl-glycidyl ether (AGE), cyclohexene oxide (CHO) as the substrate, respectively. As shown in Table 2 , most cyclic carbonates can be efficiently synthesized from the corresponding epoxides, which were respectively confirmed by 1H NMR (Fig. S12). However, when CHO was employed, only 33.97% conversion was observed. The low conversion of CHO is ascribed to the steric hindrance, which made the ring opening of CHO difficult to occur [59]. Additionally, the obtained 3-Butoxy-1, 2-propylene carbonate from CHO conversion was only the cis isomer, which has been confirmed by previous literature [60]. As a result, a low conversion of CHO was gained. In addition, when the catalytic system was charged with additional 1.0 wt.% ethanol (methanol) of PO, almost all of PO molecule were converted into PC. While the additive was replaced by equivalent water, the conversion of PO is only 17.94%, and the selectivity decreased to from 98.61% (98.83%) to 86.97%, indicating that the hydrogen atom of ethanol hydroxyl showed a higher activity for ring opening of epoxide. Besides, addition of water molecule into reaction system can promote PO hydrolysis into 1,2-propanediol, resulting in a decreasing selectivity to PC. 3.5 Mechanism and DFT studies Carbon dioxide coupling with epoxide includes the ring opening of epoxide, CO2 insertion into ring-opening intermediate, and intermediate ring closure, of which the ring opening of epoxide was the rate-determining step [61, 62], as the coupling process can be efficiently promoted in the presence of Lewis acid-basic sites simultaneously. Interestingly, the existence of Lewis acid sites within Zn (II) complexes have been validated by NH3-TPD profiles (Fig. 5I), while the nitrogen-containing ligand constructing the crystal structure has the function to serve as Lewis basic sites [63, 64], and as also confirmed by CO2-adsorption (Fig. 5II). Therefore, a possible reaction pathway was proposed with reference to the previous reports [65-67]. As shown in Scheme 3 , the epoxide was firstly activated by Zinc node, and then formed a ring-opening intermediate which was thereafter attacked by CO2 to produce another intermediate. Subsequently, the intermediate underwent ring closure to release cyclic carbonate, as well as generate Zn-based complex. In order to confirm the reliability of the proposed mechanism to illustrate the coupling process, the G09 package was adopted for studying the transition state and intermediate. The corresponding theoretical calculations for the coupling reactions catalyzed by oMyPbh-ZnI2 is exhibited in Figs. 8 and 9 . The energy barrier of the transition state increases in the order: 2.07 kcal/mol (Ring closure, TS3) < 3.99 kcal/mol (CO2 insertion, TS2) < 31.00 kcal/mol (Ring opening, TS1), indicated that the ring-opening transition state was the key step for CO2 cycloaddition. Moreover, the ring-opening transition state in the coupling process has also been reported by previous literatures [61, 62], which is also considered as the rate-determining step for similar reactions. Additionally, the reaction process catalyzed by oMyPbh-ZnX2 (X=Br− and Cl−) has also been calculated with the results showing a similar trend with that enhanced by oMyPbh-ZnI2. It can also be found that the difference in catalytic activity of oMyPbh-ZnX2 (X=Br− and Cl−) was also related to the CO2 inserting into ring opening intermediate and the ring closure of subsequently-formed intermediates. Conclusions In the present work, the catalytic performance of simply-synthesized Zn (II) complexes were evaluated in facilitation of CO2 coupling with epoxide. The oMyPbh-ZnI2 was found with the highest catalytic performance among the studied Zn-based samples, suggesting that the CO2 insertion and ring closure of the formed intermediate easily occur in the presence of iodide ion ligands. Besides, the highest yield consisting of 98.62% conversion of ECH and 96.97% selectivity to CPC can be obtained when the reaction system was charged with 2.5 MPa of CO2 molecule and 1.25 wt.% catalyst of ECH heated at 110 °C for 8 h. Moreover, it was also found that methanol/ethanol as the additive has an obviously positive effect on the coupling process. Importantly, the ring opening process of epoxide, as the rate-determining step for CO2 fixation, was confirmed by DFT calculations. coredata.dc:description: The present work aimed at comparably studying the catalytic performance of Zn (II) complexes applied as the efficient catalysts in accelerating the transformation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. The physicochemical properties of the synthesized complexes were determined by XRD, NMR, FT-IR, TGA, NH3-TPD, CO2-adsorption. The synthesized samples were found to possess the Lewis acid/basic sites derived from the zinc ions and nitrogen-containing ligands, which can synergistically catalyze the coupling reaction. In addition, the sample containing iodide ion ligands showed the highest catalytic performance compared with other Zn (II) complexes, suggesting that the amount and distribution of the Lewis acid sites were not the primary factors for determining the catalytic activity, and the difference in activity of halogen ion ligands (I−, Br−, Cl−) has a larger influence on the coupling process, which made the CO2 insertion and ring closure of the formed intermediate more easily occur when iodide ion ligands participated. It can be drawn that the catalytic activity of the Zn (II) complexes was simultaneously associated with halide ion ligands and substitution group of the ligand. Moreover, 98.62% conversion of epichlorohydrin (ECH) and 96.97% selectivity to chloropropene carbonate (TOF=56.65 h − 1) was achieved at the optimal operation parameters (110 °C, 2.5 MPa, 8 h, 1.25 wt.% catalyst of ECH). Furthermore, the proposed pathway of CO2 coupling with epoxide was confirmed by DFT calculation, with the result confirming that the process of epoxide ring opening was the key step for the coupling reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Experimental and computational studies of Zn (II) complexes structured with Schiff base ligands as the efficient catalysts for chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates
